comments:
I'm having the following problem while making some update or sync in the cvs:

scbr15: cvs update: cannot open directory /home/dev/cvs/CVSROOT/EmptyDir/source/python/soil/tests/test_soilintegration: No such file or directory

cvs version: 1.12.13 (on linux)

Note that the EmptyDir is actually an empty directory, so, I'm not sure why this is happening. I had this in 2 projects, and in one of those I decided to delete it and get it from the cvs again, and it seems to work without problems (only the hassle of having to re-configure the whole project). That project was 'upgraded' from Eclipse 3.1 (might be related).

When I've created the project I did it with the 'new simple project wizard' and then used the 'new project from cvs' to get only the packages I wanted to that previously created project.

I simply cannot use that project anymore with cvs for update or sync (but I seem to be able to commit).

-------------------
eclipse.buildId=I20060526-0010
java.version=1.4.2_03
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.

-------------------

An error occurred synchronizing /scbr15: The following warnings were reported while performing the "cvs update" command
-------------------

We would like to try and reproduce the problem but we need more information. Could you provide more details of the folder setup and the st3eps required to produce the failure?

Well, after that problem, I decided to recreate my workspace in Eclipse 3.2 and had no problems so far (seems like something when migrating from one to the other).

So, unfortunatelly, I've already deleted that old workspace and don't have the steps to reproduce it reliably (so, if you want to close this bug it'd be ok for me)... I've used that workspace for over a year before the migration, migrating from 3.0 to 3.1 and only had problems now when migrating to 3.2, so, I'm not sure if there is some particular thing I did to cause that behaviour.

Thanks,

Fabio
OK, I'll close it. Feel free to reopen if you see it again.

Ok, I've been able to duplicate it on version 3.2 from scratch.

What I'm doing is: 

1. Created a simple project
2. Gotten some root folders from the cvs and added them to that project
3. Repeated same process with other computer (so, we now have comp1 and comp2 with the same contents)

4. Use comp1 to add a new folder under one of that root directories and add some new file to the it
5. Commit that folder and the files
6. Do an update on the project root on comp2 (it should get all things without problems)
7. When trying to synchronize on the project root, it will give that error saying  "cannot open the ...EmptyDir... no such file or directory" on that exact directory.

It's strange because this does not happen with the initial folders gotten.

the cvs version is: 1.12.13 (on linux)
and Eclipse is on windows xp

Same Problem here: We are using Projects with attached "modules" as Folders. The Project has the Repository-Entry "CVSROOT\Emptydir" and the Folders the (correct) "source". When Trying to replace or update at the Project or Root-Folder, I get messages like:
Error: eGecko-Control-Branch: cvs update: cannot open directory /cvs/css/CVSROOT/Emptydir/source/de/css/faktura/beleg/artikelstamm: No such file or directory

Updating the Folder manually gets the Content, but the Repository-File contains the Path "CVSROOT/Emptydir/source/..." instead of "source/...".

Ps: We updated workspace and projects from 3.1 to 3.2

Ok, I've just checked the "Repository" file here and it too is checked-out with /CVSROOT/EmptyDir/xxx

If I just strip that part ("/CVSROOT/EmptyDir/") out and do an update, it works.
*** Bug 148945 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created an attachment (id=46007)
A little plugin to work around that problem and cleanup botchy CVS-informations

The plugin checks the Repository files and discards the CVSROOT/Emptydir where found. I hope it will leave real emptydirs as is (i.e. the project). Click right mouse button on any Folder oder Project and select "CVS-Cleanup" -> "Remove Emptydirs" (but do it on your own risk ^^). Please contact me if you have trouble with it or want to see the source.
With greetings from Germany

Steve

I have the same problem with the same log/exception message. The plugin from Steve Ulrich can't solve this problem in my case. Only removing the complete directory path and "replace with latest from head" make a cvs sync/update possible.

We've been experiencing this as well.  It only occurs when you are using modules comprised of modules.  A simple module would not reproduce it here for us, nor would a normal non-module CVS project.  My steps to reproduce it consistently here:

1) Create a new Project, testproj
2) Add a folder, folder
3) Add a file, file.txt
4) Share testproj
5) Check out CVSROOT
6) Add testproj/folder as a module, testfolder
 6a) Edit the CVSROOT/modules file
 6b) Add line: testfolder testproj/folder
 6c) Add line: testmodule &testfolder
 6d) Save, Commit
7) Check out testmodule
8) Check out testmodule again as testmodule2
9) Add a new folder to testmodule/testfolder, folder2
10) Add a file to that folder, file2.txt
11) Commit changes to testmodule
12) Update testmodule2 from CVS
13) testmodule2 will not be broken
 13a) Attempt to synchronize, it will fail:
  'testmodule2: cvs update: cannot open directory /var/lib/cvsroot/CVSROOT/Emptydir/testfolder/folder2/file2.txt: No such file or directory'
 13b) The CVS/Repository entry for testfolder/folder2 will show:
  'CVSROOT/Emptydir/testfolder/folder2'
  which is obviously wrong.

Somehow CVSROOT and Emptydir get stuck in the Repository source for the new folders.  This happens every time, and of our projects are psuedo-modules like this, so it's a bit frustrating.  Hopefully this information helps diagnose the issue!

Eclipse 3.2 on Windows XP, Solaris 8, happens on both
CVS pserver v1.11.17 Solaris 8

If more information is needed I'd be happy to share.

Thanks.
Ack, step 13: testmodule2 will *NOW* be broken, not not.  Definitely not not. :)

I'm having this problem as well.  I cannot synchronize or update from my CVS repository.  The project was created in 3.1 and the problem arose after I migrated my eclipse to 3.2.  My workspace consists of several CVS modules that were imported into a single, non-source controlled project.  I cannot synchronize any folder.  Here is some version info and the log trace:

Patch that fixes the problem

Here's a patch that fixes the problem. I will release it to 3.3 and 3.2.1 after I run the tests.
*** Bug 154816 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
The problem is fixed for updates, but it still happens when committing cvs changes. Please reopen bug.
This bug report has nothing to do with committing. If you see a problem on commit then please open a separate bug report.
